(LPG)  in  the  Islamic  Republic  of  Afghanistan,  incorporated  in

Project Description  The project will develop a nationwide LPG storage and distribution 
network  in  Afghanistan.  LPG  is  the  only  practical  and  feasible 
substitute for firewood and animal dung as a primary fuel source.  
Increased LPG consumption improves the environment, improves 
living conditions, and accelerates economic growth through more 
efficient use of, and enhanced access to, energy for households 
and small businesses. 
 
The project imports LPG directly from refineries in Turkmenistan 
and  Uzbekistan,  and  delivers  LPG  to  consumer  households 
through  an  efficient  supply  chain  with  no  intermediaries.  The 
project provides the following deliverables to consumer household 
beneficiaries: 
 
Environmental. Compared with solid fuels currently used in many 
households,  LPG  reduces  ambient  air  pollution  in  cities  and 
reduces harmful fumes within households. 
 
Safety. The project will contribute to reducing death and accidents 
caused by illegal products and inexperienced distributors. 
 
Energy. LPG has a higher calorific value, is more efficient to burn 
than solid fuels, and provides long-run cost savings to consumers.  
It is more diverse as it can be used in applications other than just 
open combustion.

ii   
Economic. Households using LPG are more productive, especially 
women and children, enabling more time for studying and working; 
family  productivity  increases.  Small  businesses  benefit  from  a 
reliable and uninterrupted fuel supply without the burden of using 
their own employees or family members to collect firewood. 
  
Impact,  Outcome,  and  Impacts. Improved access to modern energy sources facilitating 
Benefits  economic growth and well-being, decreased use of traditional solid 
fuels for energy, private sector investment in Afghanistan's energy 
infrastructure. 
 
Outcome. Increased retail supply of affordable, high quality LPG in 
a safe and reliable manner with an additional 230,000 households 
switching from traditional solid fuels to LPG by 2019. 
 
Benefits. Higher and more dispersed availability of LPG, lower 
exposure to local pollutants such as suspended particulate matter, 
a safer and more reliable energy supply system as opposed to the 
existing gray market system (which is unsafe and unreliable), and 
alleviation of energy poverty in the country. 
 
The  project's  direct  benefits  include  the  provision  of  clean, 
affordable, reliable energy to households and small businesses, 
and the creation of 340 jobs by 2014.   
 
The  project  significantly  benefits  women  and  children,  who  are 
often the more vulnerable to the adverse health impacts of solid 
fuel smoke and suspended particulate matter emissions. Women 
and children further benefit by no longer having to spend time 
collecting firewood, and instead have time to pursue education and 
other  activities  that  contribute  to  household  productivity  and 
income. Small businesses also receive direct benefits by reducing 
harmful  smoke  and  particulates  in  the  workplace,  increasing 
worker safety and productivity. 
   
Borrower/Project  The  sponsors  are  three  well-regarded  non-resident  Afghan 
Sponsors  businessmen,  each  with  a  long  history  of  establishing  and 
operating  successful  businesses  in  petroleum  products  and 
consumer  goods  packaging  and  distribution.  Each  has 
demonstrated the ability to operate successfully in the challenging 
business environment of Afghanistan. 
   
Investment Cost and  The company is planning to invest a total of $58.2 million through 
Financing Plan  2019 to build LPG refilling centers in five Afghan cities and to 
acquire additional LPG fuel cylinders for distribution to consumers. 
ADB is seeking Board approval to subscribe up to $8 million in 
company  preference  shares.  In  addition  to  paid-in  capital,  the 
company will plough back cash flow from operations and raise 
short-term debt from local relationship banks to fund its capital 
expenditure program.

iii
Proposed ADB  An equity investment of up to $8,000,000 from the ordinary capital 
Assistance  resources  of  ADB  to  stimulate  the  capital  investment  and 
development  objectives  of  the  company,  with  the  intention  of 
exiting the investment by 2019 through either a share sale, put 
option, or call option, under such terms and conditions as have 
been approved by ADB's Investment Committee. 
  
Implementation  Sungas Ltd. began implementing its business plan as originally 
Arrangements  envisioned and has completed the construction and commissioning 
of two bulk storage facilities and one refilling center, with another 
refilling center to be fully commissioned by 2010. ADB's investment 
and  the  company's  other  financing  sources  will  fund  three 
additional  refilling  centers  and  the  purchase  of  LPG  cylinders.  
Construction  is  being  performed  by  Sungas  Ltd.  using  local 
contractors and imported LPG equipment, vessels, and piping.   
   
Risks and Mitigating  Any  investment  in  Afghanistan  is  at  risk  of  being  negatively

However, the risks are mitigated by the sponsors' experience in the 
country  and  the  project's  ability  to  scale  up  or  down  with  the 
market.  The development impact outweighs the risks. 
 
Realization of benefits from the project relies on a sustained or 
improved security situation, relative macroeconomic stability, and a 
continued pro-business policy environment. Specific project-related 
risks include: 
(i)  market risk, 
(ii)  product quality and safety, 
(iii)  sponsor, management and reputational risk, 
(iv)  regulatory and political risk, 
(v)  foreign exchange and price risk, 
(vi)  security risk, 
(vii)  insurance availability,  
(viii)  ADB influence over strategy and direction, and

Justification / ADB  The  investment  stimulates  the  expansion  of  a  company  that 
Value-Added  demonstrates  adherence  to  business  ethics  and  international 
safety standards. The rationale for the timing and the amount of 
investment is to enable the company to achieve its franchising 
strategy by installing LPG distribution capacity in locations where 
distributor demand is highest, thus increasing the supply of safe 
and  reliable  LPG  to  household  users.  ADB's  support  of  this 
expansion  will  encourage  commercial  lenders,  international 
investors,  and  aid  agencies  to  support  broader  private  sector 
development in a wider range of industries in Afghanistan. ADB's 
assistance provides capital to the company at a critical time in the 
business plan rollout, thereby supporting the generation of brand 
awareness,  construction  of  infrastructure  and  facilities,  and 
expansion of retail sales channels.

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed 
equity investment in Sungas Limited Liability Corporation (Sungas LLC) of up to $8,000,000 or 
25%  of  the  company's  total  paid-in  share  capital,  whichever  is  less.  Sungas  LLC,  is  the 
Delaware, United States, registered holding company of Sungas Limited (Sungas Ltd.), which is 
a distributor of liquefied petroleum gas (LPG) in the Islamic Republic of Afghanistan. The design 
and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  BACKGROUND AND RATIONALE 
A.  Project Identification and Selection 
2.  The sponsors first approached Asian Development Bank (ADB) in July 2005 to invite its 
participation  in  the  expansion  of  Sungas's  nationwide  LPG  storage  and  distribution 
infrastructure. After a series of meetings in November 2005 and a site visit by the project team 
to Afghanistan in December 2005, Sungas submitted its business plan to ADB in late 2005, with 
a request for financing. The project received concept clearance on 20 March 2006, and due 
diligence  missions  were  conducted  in  April  and  September  2006.  Complex  financial  and 
corporate structuring has continued since 2007, with Sungas now in a position for ADB to 
subscribe to shares. Given the nature and location of the project, it was subjected to very 
rigorous due diligence and structuring. The rationale for ADB's participation in the project is to 
support Afghanistan's growth by catalyzing private sector development and facilitating access to 
modern energy sources. LPG is clean and safe. It has the least demanding infrastructure 
requirements of the energy alternatives and has the potential to dramatically improve living 
conditions for the poor. 
 
3.  Modern  energy  is  a  prerequisite  for  development.  According  to  the  United  Nations 
Development Programme (UNDP),1 access to greater quality and quantity of energy is essential 
for the poor to make the transition from subsistence livelihoods to improved productivity, income 
generation, and living standards. Services enabled by modern energy (such as heat, light, 
motive  power,  and  refrigeration)  are  pivotal  contributors  to  human  welfare  and  economic 
development. Studies link access to modern energy to improved human welfare as measured 
by  the  human  development  index  (HDI).2  Afghanistan  ranks  173rrd  out  of  178  surveyed 
countries in the HDI.3 Kabul energy consumption data4 indicate that over 60% of Afghanistan's 
energy  consumption  is  provided  by  firewood.  For  the  poorest  people  and countries, small 
incremental increases in access to modern energy lead to dramatic gains in the HDI. 
 
4.  Providing  the  poor  with  access  to  clean,  affordable  modern  energy  improves 
productivity, education, health, and gender equality. Access to modern energy frees the poor, 
especially  women  and  girls,  from  the  drudgery  of  collecting  firewood,  thus  expanding 
opportunities for schooling and after-school study. Use of clean modern energy also reduces

animal  dung)  for  cooking  and  heating.  Shifting  to  cleaner-burning  LPG  reduces  carbon

5.  While natural gas supplied by pipeline is typically more economical in the long run than 
LPG  transported  by  tanker  trucks,  the  absence  of  a  nationwide  pipeline  network  and  the 
prohibitive construction costs for pipelines over long distances in the near term imply that 
achieving a wide distribution of LPG will rely on road-based transportation. According to the 
World Bank, a natural gas pipeline to Kabul from the north and the use of unconfirmed domestic 
natural  gas  in  the  south  are  not yet  viable  or  cost-effective.5    Considering  these  factors, 
Sungas’s capital investments can be easily scaled according to market conditions, i.e., trucks 
and cylinders can be added or scaled back more readily and at a lower cost than permanently 
installed piping from terminals to distribution centers. 
 
6.  LPG offers an attainable-cost solution to consumers using firewood and other cheaper 
alternatives, who are typically not in a position to pay for switching to piped natural gas because 
of high initial conversion costs. Even in higher-income, gas-rich countries, for example in Latin 
America, the urban poor continue to use LPG, although it has a higher price per energy unit 
than natural gas, because they cannot afford the connection to the natural gas pipeline system. 
 
B.  Sector Background

7.  The three major fuels in the energy basket of Afghanistan's households are firewood 
(35%), animal dung (19%), and vegetation brush (18%). The share of LPG in the total energy 
demand by Afghanistan's households stands at 9%. The bulk of LPG use in Afghanistan is for 
domestic cooking, and secondarily for lighting and winter heating, with many households that 
use LPG for cooking continuing to use firewood for heating. Use of LPG is greater among urban 
households, whose share in energy consumption is 33%, compared to 2% for rural households. 
 
8.  An independent market consultant,6 commissioned to validate Sungas’s market strategy, 
revealed that in only 6 of 34 provinces (Balkh, Herat, Jawzjan, Kabul, Mazar-e-Sharif, Nimroz, 
and Panjsher) do a significant number of households use LPG for any or all of the three uses, 
namely cooking, heating, and lighting. Low LPG usage rates are found in five other provinces 
(Baghlan, Kandhar, Kapisa, Kunduz, and Takhar). In rural provinces like Bamyan, Daikindi, 
Farah,  Ghor,  Kunarha,  Laghman,  Nuristan,  Paktika,  Sar-i-poul,  and  Zabul,  almost  no 
households use LPG for all or any of the three uses. Kabul alone accounts for more than half of 
the country’s total consumption of LPG, while the combined consumption of Kabul, Mazar-e-
Sharif, and Herat accounts for a majority. 
 
9.  Residential LPG use in Kabul, as a proportion of total fuel use, is presently estimated at 
only 18% (Table 1), suggesting significant potential demand for LPG in the residential urban 
market.  Kabul's  non-LPG  urban  consumers  exhibit  similar  consumption  patterns  to  rural 
households, resorting to heavy biomass consumption because of the lack of access to other 
fuels, economic factors, and tradition. The environmental consequences in Kabul, particularly in

2.  Forecasted Demand Growth

10.  Higher income growth  in the coming years will not only add more LPG-consuming 
households, but it will also increase the consumption of LPG in existing households. Income 
elasticity, estimated by an independent market consultant, implies that demand for LPG could 
rise faster than increases in gross domestic product (GDP) per capita, which is consistent with 
income elasticity of demand in other developing countries such as India, Pakistan, and People's 
Republic of China (footnote 6). GDP growth has averaged 7.5% per year.7 
 
11.  Demand varies  by city and state, taking into account population growth, household size, 
GDP per capita growth, position on the energy ladder8, and LPG availability. A detailed scenario 
analysis suggests that rapid growth is likely with total LPG demand increasing many times over 
the next 10 years. This trend is consistent with other countries that have transitioned from 
gathered biomass fuels to LPG, such as Turkey, India, and Pakistan.   
 
3.  Supply and Competition

12.  As there is no domestic production of LPG in Afghanistan, demand is met through 
imports. The supply chain is composed of a number of importers, wholesalers, and unorganized 
retailers. Besides the government, which imports for its own use and limited retail operations, a 
small number of importers buy bulk LPG9 from refineries in either Turkmenistan or Uzbekistan, 
import the LPG in railcars or tanker trucks, and offload it to LPG tanker trucks for transportation 
to  independent  distributors  at  wholesale  prices.  The  distributors  repackage  the  LPG  into 
cylinders, which are sold to end-users by individual retailers in the main cities and trading 
centers. 
 
13.  The  threat  of  new  market  entrants  in  direct  competition  with  Sungas  does  exist; 
however, there are a number of barriers that prevent supply-side overcrowding. The most 
significant barrier is the difficulty in establishing supply chain and procurement relationships with 
the most economical sources of LPG available to Afghanistan, and these relationships take time 
to establish. Other significant barriers to entry include the cost of bulk storage facilities and 
associated  LPG  unloading  equipment,  and  obtaining  Afghanistan  regulatory  approvals  for 
import licensing and facility construction. 
 
14.  There  is  a  substantial  quantity  of  illegal10  or  under-invoiced  supplies  of  LPG  in 
Afghanistan, whose pricing could disrupt the company's market penetration. These gray market 
suppliers, however, do not offer a consistent product or safe storage and refilling of LPG.  
Based on data when the independent market study was conducted in 2007, total imports in 
2005 amounted to just 16,190 tons, whereas the total estimated LPG usage in Afghanistan for 
that year was approximately 150,000 tons. The independent market consultant suggested that 
this  difference  is  explained  by  inadequate  statistical  reporting  systems,  under-invoicing  of 
imports, and illegal imports.   
 
15.  Consumer demand exceeds Sungas's current supply capacity as many LPG consumers 
perceive their existing suppliers as being unreliable and providing an inconsistent and unsafe 
product.  During  2008,  there  were  a  total  of  5,610  deaths  in  Afghanistan  from  accidents 
occurring from either misuse or the use of unsafe LPG cylinders. Customers regard Sungas' 
cylinder inspection and maintenance process as a key product differentiator.  
 
4.  Market Regulation, Pricing, and Affordability 
[CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION HAS BEEN DELETED] 
 
16.  The LPG market in Afghanistan is currently not subject to quality standards or control 
regulations other than import classification, which is not always tightly controlled. As a result, 
product quality is variable, and at times very poor. Import and distribution of LPG are not subject 
to licensing other than regular business license requirements. 
 
17.  LPG prices are market-based. Consistent with international best practice, Afghanistan 
does not subsidize LPG. LPG sales prices are subject to competition and adjusted in line with 
changes  in  the  LPG  purchase  price  and  transportation costs, both  of  which are  linked  to 
international petroleum prices. The retail price of LPG in Afghanistan is typically about double its 
international  price  because  of  higher  supply  costs  and  margins  charged  by  importers,

18.  The  demand  for  LPG  in  Afghanistan  is  highly  price-sensitive.  The  LPG  market  in 
Afghanistan is characterized by a long supply chain with numerous middleman sales, which 
drives  up  prices  and  applies  downward  pressure  on  consumer  demand.  However,  an 
independent market expert determined that LPG pricing in the country is market-based, and 
suppliers  offset  downward  trends  in  demand  by  reducing  their  margins.  Sungas,  the  only 
vertically integrated supplier, has a better cost position and more flexibility by which to reduce its 
margins, meet consumer affordability constraints, and remain profitable. 
 
5.  Industry Competitiveness and Profitability 
19.  Neither the government nor any private sector operator operates a nationwide LPG 
network able to exploit economies of scale. No organization operating in the LPG market in any 
part of the supply chain has a dominant share of the market. Barriers to entry, though they exist, 
are not strong enough to give any single firm absolute dominance. 
 
20.  The  low  level  of  concentration  in  the  supply  chain,  comparatively  easy  licensing 
procedures, low customs duty, and the absence of any price regulation, make Afghanistan's 
LPG  market  fully  competitive,  although  this may  be  more  a  result of  market  infancy  than 
implemented policy. A vertically integrated LPG business has strong potential for profitability 
since it delivers LPG to the end-consumer at a lower cost compared with the current supply 
chain,  where  profit  is  extracted  numerous  times  as  LPG  is  bought  and  sold  between 
intermediaries. Given the absence of strong incumbents, Sungas, which is vertically integrated 
from import to consumer sales with an emphasis on brand safety and reliability, should have a 
strong first-mover advantage. 
 
C.  Alignment with ADB Strategy and Operations  
21.  The project is aligned with ADB's strategies and operational objectives, providing safer 
and improved access to a modern fuel supply with direct benefits to economic and social 
development.  
 
1.  Consistency with Strategy 2020 
22.  Strategy 2020 identifies the energy sector as a core operational sector.11  Catalyzing 
investments  through  increased  private  sector  participation  in  ADB's  developing  member 
countries is one of the five strategic priorities. The project contributes to inclusive economic 
growth by connecting more Afghans to energy infrastructure, which increases their household 
productivity and alleviates much of the deprivation that currently exists among women and 
children, who spend valuable time collecting firewood and biomass for cooking and heating.  
The project addresses an infrastructure deficit, which Strategy 2020 broadly recognizes as a 
constraint to market-led growth and a proliferator of environmental damage. The project delivers 
not only improved infrastructure in the form of built assets, but also an improvement in energy 
delivery services, which creates an enabling environment for the private sector in terms of both 
fuel supply and opportunities to participate as distributors.

2.  Consistency with the Country Strategy 
23.  ADB's country partnership strategy for Afghanistan12 recognizes the critical importance 
of  the  energy  sector  for  economic  growth,  private  sector  development,  and  employment 
creation.  Since lack of access to both power and energy resources is a key constraint to a 
country's development, ADB will work with the Ministry of Energy and Water to improve service 
delivery, promote efficiency, and build capacity across the sector. The project complements the 
efforts of ADB’s Central and West Asia Department to promote increased access to energy 
services by providing downstream distribution assets linking more Afghan households to LPG. 
 
3.  Consistency with the Energy Policy 2009 
24.  The Energy Policy emphasizes promotion of energy sector reforms, governance, and 
capacity building as one of the advancements necessary for maximizing access to energy for 
all. The project contributes to this objective by assisting a well-organized company that complies 
with  Afghanistan's  regulatory  procedures—both  those  already  established  and  ones  being 
developed—and connects efficient delivery of energy products and services with best practice 
energy sector policies, reducing illegal imports and unsafe grey-market distribution. 
 
25.  Extensive use of traditional biomass results in a higher incidence of health problems, 
and the Energy Policy cites World Health Organization data that almost 1.6 million people, 
mostly women and children, die every year around the world from exposure to this pollution.  
The typical transition for poor rural people is to switch from traditional biomass to coal, charcoal, 
and kerosene, which are improved sources over traditional biomass, yet their health, safety, and 
environmental  (HSE)  effects  are  not  sustainable.  The  project  directly  delivers  the  Energy 
Policy's preferred option of LPG as a fuel source and also implements an efficient delivery 
system that will lower the cost of switching from traditional fuel sources to LPG. 
 
26.  ADB is a major source of external assistance to the energy sector in Afghanistan, having 
provided  over  $350  million  of  lending  assistance,  $23  million  in  grants,  and  $8  million  in 
technical assistance to the energy sector. The focus of sovereign lending assistance has been 
on hydropower development, infrastructure rehabilitation and reconstruction, and transmission 
and distribution. ADB's nonlending assistance has focused on sector reviews, feasibility studies,

centers. ADB's support of this expansion will foster confidence among commercial lenders,

(i)  Catalyzes private investment in a security-challenged developing member

expansion. The success of the company’s business will demonstrate to other 
private  investors  that  positive  outcomes  are  achievable.  ADB's  successful

economic growth by connecting more Afghans to energy infrastructure, which 
increases their household productivity and alleviates much of the deprivation that 
currently exists among women and children, who spend valuable time collecting 
firewood and biomass for cooking and heating. The project connects more of the 
country's low income households to efficient power and energy resources, which 
are  key  enablers  in  reducing  poverty.  Additionally,  the  project  facilitates  the 
transition for poor rural people switching from traditional biomass directly to LPG 
rather than through the typical intermediate fuels such as coal, charcoal, and 
kerosene, which have unsustainable HSE effects.   
 
(iii)  Promotes corporate governance. Through its role as a shareholder and its 
board representation, ADB can influence corporate governance practices and 
help the company develop into a role model for other ventures in Afghanistan.

companies  in  the  sponsors'  spheres  of  interest  and  by  other  companies  in 
Afghanistan.

project has facilitated the adoption of environmental and social safeguards. The 
initial  environmental  examination,  conducted  in  2007,  prompted  public 
consultation, which generated significant support from local stakeholders and 
officials,  and  ensured  the  creation  of  an  HSE  policy  developed  by  Bureau 
Veritas, and implementation of an EMP. 
 
C.  Risks and Mitigation Measures 
72.  Investments in Afghanistan, by nature of the political and commercial environment, are 
exposed to a high degree of political, commercial, and security risk. Nevertheless, unless a 
multilateral financial institution like ADB takes the lead in structuring such transactions and 
helps to mitigate the risks, projects will stall, as other means of financing are practically non-
existent at present. Notwithstanding the risk environment, the project has inherent risk mitigation 
through very experienced sponsors, a wide distribution of scalable assets, and fundamental 
market demand. Specific identified risks and their mitigants include: 
 
(i)  Market risk.  There is currently no regulatory regime for the LPG market in 
Afghanistan.  There are also significant price volatilities since supply and demand 
levels are subject to availability and seasonality.  ADB has conducted extensive 
due diligence over several years on the sponsors and on the market, including 
engaging an independent consultant with experience in the LPG market.  Market 
data show that there is a ready and substantial market for LPG across the

16  
country, especially for household consumption, and that as household income 
increases,  consumers  would  tend  to  shift  to  cleaner  fuels.  The  consultant 
validated the sponsors' expectations and market opportunities, and the market 
forecast was used as the basis for the company's financial model. ADB will work 
with the company through the board of directors to ensure business decisions 
and their execution are consistent with the strategy.   
 
(ii)  Product quality and safety. ADB commissioned an independent audit on HSE 
issues, which validated that the installed equipment conformed with international 
standards and the handling of LPG with quality control best practices. The final 
HSE report outlines recommended management plans that have been adopted 
by Sungas as corporate policies and procedures. Sungas is thus employing 
product and safety standards used in developed markets and well in excess of 
those currently seen in Afghanistan. 
 
(iii)  Sponsor,  management,  and  reputational  risk. The sponsors are individual 
investors, and ADB does not typically invest alongside individual sponsors as 
partners  due  to  issues  related  to  compliance,  know-your-customer  (KYC) 
principles, transparency in terms of funding sources, creditworthiness, related 
party transactions, conflict of interest and succession. However, there are few 
alternatives in making significant development impacts through the private sector 
in Afghanistan, given the lack of commercial interest. With this environment, ADB 
has therefore selected a group of sponsors who are well-reputed in the local 
context.  Sponsor risk is further mitigated by having safeguard mechanisms in 
place, and by ADB having a unilateral put option, allowing ADB to exit for any 
reason  at  any  time.    Given  the  lack  of  exposure  of  the  sponsors  to  the 
commercial  credit  markets,  a  comprehensive  integrity  investigation  was 
commissioned to address potential reputational risk to ADB. An international risk 
management consulting firm, hired by ADB, conducted a multi-country search 
and  investigation  into  the  business  interests  and  personal  history  of  each 
sponsor, their relatives, and their business associates. The investigation revealed 
no reputational risk for ADB and highlighted the prominent standing of these 
business leaders in Afghanistan.     
 
(iv)  Regulatory and political risk. The regulatory environment in Afghanistan is still 
developing. However, given Sungas's high quality supply of LPG to meet the 
current  market  demand,  and  the  prominence  of  the  sponsors,  the  risk  of 
regulatory and political interference is manageable. 
 
(v)  Foreign  exchange  and  price  risk.  The  company's  cash  flows  will  be 
denominated  in  afghani,  whereas  dividend  payments  to  the  investors  and 
purchases of LPG imports will be in foreign currency. Working capital funding 
and hedging instruments are not available in Afghanistan. Foreign exchange risk 
is partially mitigated by the international benchmarking of the LPG retail price in 
dollars, and through a cost-plus mechanism on retail sales of LPG such that price 
volatilities can be passed on to consumers.  However, the afghani could devalue 
to the point where the demand elasticity imposes a ceiling on the retail price. At 
this point, Sungas would be unable to pass on further exchange rate increases; 
however, it could sell excess LPG internationally. This contingency is further 
mitigated by the recent performance of the afghani which, since its introduction in 
February 2003, has substantially held its value and is freely convertible.

17
 
(vi)  Security  risk.  The  recently  deteriorating  security  situation  can  delay  project 
implementation  and  pose  threats  to  employees  and  infrastructure.  It  can 
constrain the company in distributing its products and severely impact its ability 
to realize its sales and profits forecasts. However, the company is supplying a 
basic  commodity  and  it  has  a  flexible  program  for  build-up,  roll-out,  and 
distribution, which can cater to changes in the security situation and market. 
 
(vii)  Insurance availability. Sungas has obtained insurance coverage on its fixed 
assets from a London-based insurer. Losses are covered under typical weather 
damage, operational damage, and damage caused by vehicles; however, acts of 
war  and  terrorism  are  excluded  and  not  available  from  alternate  insurers  in 
Afghanistan. Losses to the company's fleet of tanker trucks are not covered 
under any policy as the cost to insure the fleet is not commensurate with the 
book value of the assets. 
 
(viii)  ADB influence over strategy and direction. ADB will work with the sponsors to 
establish and enforce acceptable governance procedures to protect the interests 
of ADB as a minority investor and to prepare the company for ADB's timely exit 
after development impact has been demonstrated. 
 
D.  Assurances 
73.  Consistent  with  the  Agreement  Establishing  the  Asian  Development  Bank, 15 the 
Government of Afghanistan will be requested to confirm that it has no objection to the proposed 
assistance to Sungas via ADB's investment in Sungas LLC.  ADB will enter into suitable finance 
documentation, in form and substance satisfactory to ADB, following approval of the proposed 
assistance by the ADB Board of Directors. 
 
 
 
 
V.  RECOMMENDATION 
 
74.  I am satisfied that the proposed investment would comply with the Articles of Agreement 
of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and, acting in the absence of the President, under the 
provisions of Article 35.1 of the Articles of Agreement of ADB, I recommend that the Board 
approve the equity investment of up to the lesser of $8,000,000 and 25% of the issued and paid 
up share capital in Sungas LLC for the LPG Distribution Development Project from ADB’s 
ordinary capital resources, on terms and conditions as are substantially in accordance with 
those set forth in this report, and as may be reported to the Board.

I.  POVERTY ANALYSIS AND STRATEGY 
A.  Link to the National Poverty Reduction Strategy and Country Partnership Strategy  
The country partnership strategy for Afghanistan (2009–2013)a has identified the limited availability and poor quality of power 
infrastructure  (only  6%  of  the  population  has  access  to  electricity)  as  one  of  the  factors  undermining  the  country's 
competitiveness, economic opportunities, and delivery of social services such as education, health care, and security. The 
project, which will develop a nationwide liquefied petroleum gas (LPG) storage and distribution network in Afghanistan, will 
promote increased access to energy services by providing downstream distribution assets linking more Afghan households to 
LPG. The project is consistent with the 2009 Energy Policy as it directly delivers the Energy Policy's preferred option of LPG 
as a fuel source and also implements an efficient delivery system that will lower the cost of switching from traditional fuel 
sources to LPG. 
B.  Poverty Analysis                                                                  Targeting Classification: General intervention 
1.  Key Issues.  
The project connects more of the country's low income households to efficient power and energy resources, which are key 
enablers in reducing poverty. Additionally, the project facilitates the transition for poor rural people switching from traditional 
biomass directly to LPG rather than through the typical intermediate fuels such as coal, charcoal, kerosene, which have 
unsustainable health, safety, and environmental effects. The project is also expected to foster sustainable economic growth 
as small and medium-size enterprises will have easy access to a clean fuel source.  
2. Design Features 
The project will establish a nationwide LPG distribution network with a capacity of up to 190,000 tons per year by 2019.  
Funds will primarily be used for development of distribution centers in Herat, Mazar-e-Sharif, Kandahar, and Pul-e-Qumri, 
expansion of the saleable inventory of LPG cylinders, and for general capital expenditures to support the LPG storage 
terminals in Hairaton and Turghundy, expansion of the transportation fleet, and enhancement of distribution center equipment. 
C.  Poverty Impact Analysis for Policy-Based Lending 
Not applicable. 
II.  SOCIAL ANALYSIS AND STRATEGY 
A. Findings of Social Analysis 
Findings of the social assessment show that there are limited negative social impacts during construction and operation. Sites 
for the bulk storage facilities were located in areas at a safe distance from any human settlement or any public facilities. From 
the perspective of ADB's Safeguard Policy Statement (2009), the project is categorized as C. The Hairaton and Turghundy 
bulk storage facilities were constructed on vacant land near the Uzbekistan and Turkmenistan borders. These facilities, which 
were constructed on land being leased by the government to ANP, have been transferred to Sungas Ltd. at incorporation. 
Three refilling stations, each requiring 1.5 hectares of land, are being established on land purchased by Sungas. Pumping 
stations will be set up in other parts of the country on vacant land leased or purchased by Sungas either from the government 
or private owners. The selection of sites is being undertaken in such a way that involuntary resettlement is avoided. Moreover, 
Sungas only puts up pumping stations on land where lease or purchase has been freely negotiated with propery owners. 
There are a number of ethnic groups in Afghanistan, such as the Aimaks, Baloch, Brahui, Hazaras, Hindkowans, Kuchi 
Pashtuns, Tajiks, Turkmen, and Uzbek.  None of these ethnic groups has been affected as bulk storage facilities were 
constructed in industrial zones and refilling and pumping stations on leased or purchased land. The project is expected to 
improve the socioeconomic living conditions of people living in five major centers, namely, Herat, Kabul, Kandahar, and 
Mazar-e-Sharif, by providing LPG to those using traditional sources of fuel for cooking, lighting, and heating, and good quality 
fuel for public and private transportation.  
 
The project is expected to improve the socioeconomic living conditions of people living in five major centers, namely, Kabul, 
Herat, Mazar-e-Sharif, Kandahar, and Pul-e-Khumri by providing LPG to those using traditional sources of fuel for cooking, 
lighting and heating and good quality fuel for public and private transportation. During construction, approximately 40–50 
laborers were employed by construction contractors at each site. During operation, Sungas is expected to increase local labor 
staff from 108 to 336 in 5 years and to 372 by the 10th year.
